THE STATION IS LOCATED IN THE NORTH PART OF NIAGARA FALLS, ONTARIO, 1/2 MILE NORTHEAST OF THE CANADIAN NATIONAL RAILROAD YARD AND ON A ROCK SHELF ABOVE THE WHIRLPOOL.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE CUSTOMS HOUSE AT THE WEST END OF THE WHIRLPOOL RAPIDS BRG, GO NORTH AND NORTHWEST ON RIVER ROAD FOR 0.8 MILE TO THE SOUTH LANDING PORT OF THE WHIRLPOOL AERO CAR ON THE RIGHT.  CONTINUE NORTHWEST ON RIVER ROAD FOR 0.2 MILE TO THE FIRST SMALL OVERLOOK ON THE RIGHT AND THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  FROM THE OVERLOOK, PACK NORTHERLY FOR ABOUT 250 FEET, DOWNGRADE, TO A SOIL - COVERED ROCK SHELF AT THE TOP OF A HIGH CLIFF AND THE STATION. THIS IS ABOUT 50 FEET NORTH OF A SMALL WATERFALL.  THE STATION MARK, UNSTAMPED, IN A 3 - INCH IN DIAMETER BRONZE DISK SET IN THE TOP OF A CYLINDRICAL, CONCRETE POST THAT IS 9 INCHES IN DIAMETER AND 4 INCHES BELOW THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND.  IT IS 28 FEET SOUTHEAST OF AN 8 - INCH IN DIAMETER OAK TREE WITH A TRIANGULAR BLAZE.  REFERENCE 1 IS A 1 - INCH IN DIAMETER DRILL HOLE IN THE NORTH - WEST EDGE OF THE CONCRETE ABUTMENT OVER COLTS CREEK.

markers.description: DESCRIBED BY GEODETIC SURVEY OF CANADA 1909 ABOUT 1 MILE SOUTH OF VILLAGE OF GRIMSBY ON THE CANADIAN NATL RWY, ON A HIGH BLUFF ON LOT 11, CONCESSION II, ON THE WEST SIDE OF A DEEP RAVINE THAT ASCENDS SOUTHERLY FROM GRIMSBY VILLAGE.  THE STATION IS 70 PACES WEST OF THE BRINK OF THE RAVINE AND 7 PACES FROM THE NORTH EDGE OF THE ESCARPMENT.  STATION MARK, A COPPER BOLT STAMPED---G.S.C. 1912---SET IN THE BEDROCK.                            STATION RECOVERY (1941)  RECOVERY NOTE BY INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION 1941 (JGH) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED IN 1941 AND THE MARKS WERE RENEWED.  THE REVISED DESCRIPTION OF THE MARKS IS GIVEN.  STATION MARK, A COPPER BOLT STAMPED---G.S.C. 1912---SET IN THE BEDROCK (THE ORIGINAL MARK, SAID TO HAVE BEEN LEADED IN, BUT NO LEAD SHOWS AROUND IT).  THE ORIGINAL MARK WAS COVERED WITH A 2 - INCH METAL BOTTLE TOP AND A CONCRETE BLOCK 2 BY 2 FEET AND 8 INCHES HIGH WAS PLACED OVER IT.  THE STATION WAS SURFACED MARKED WITH A GEODETIC SERVICE OF CANADA STANDARD BRONZE - DISK STATION MARK SET IN THE TOP OF THE CONCRETE BLOCK.  THERE ARE THREE REFERENCES. REFERENCE NO 1 (ORIGINAL MARK) IS A COPPER BOLT LEADED INTO A HOLE IN THE BEDROCK.  REFERENCE NO 2 IS A LIKE ORIGINAL MARK SET IN A SIMILAR MANNER.  ORIGINAL REFERENCE NO 3 HAS BEEN DESTROYED.  IT WAS REPLACED BY A 3/4 - INCH DRILL HOLE 1 INCH IN DEPTH IN BARE BEDROCK 5 FEET FROM THE EDGE OF THE CLIFF.  THE AZIMUTHS AND DISTANCES TO THE REFERENCES ARE--                            STATION RECOVERY (1971)  RECOVERY NOTE BY INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION 1971 (HGD) THE STATION AND REFERENCES WERE RECOVERED AND FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  A NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS--  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 1 MILE SOUTHWEST OF THE VILLAGE OF GRIMSBY, ON A HIGH BLUFF ON LOT 11, CONCESSION II AND ON THE WEST SIDE OF A DEEP RAVINE THAT ASCENDS SOUTHERLY FROM THE VILLAGE OF GRIMSBY.  THE STATION IS 70 PACES WEST OF THE BRINK OF THE RAVINE AND 7 PACES FROM THE NORTH EDGE OF THE ESCARPMENT.  TO REACH FROM BROCKS MONUMENT IN NIAGARA FALLS, ONTARIO, TAKE QUEENS HIGHWAY TOWARDS TORONTO FOR APPROXIMATELY 25 MILES.  TAKE THE GRIMSBY EXIT AND GO TO MOUNTAIN STREET, WHICH IS THE FIRST STREET WEST OF THE TRAFFIC LIGHT.  GO TO THE TOP OF THE HILL AND TAKE THE FIRST RIGHT.  THE ROAD GOES AROUND A DEEP RAVINE, THEN TAKE THE FIRST RIGHT HAND ROAD WHICH IS QUARRY ROAD.  FOLLOW QUARRY ROAD TO THE QUARRY AND THE END OF TRUCK TRAVEL.  PACK NORTHEAST FOR ABOUT 500 FEET TO THE HIGH BLUFF AND THE STATION OVERLOOKING THE VILLAGE OF GRIMSBY.

DESCRIBED BY INTERNATIONAL WATERWAYS COMMISSION 1912 (JLS) ON THE CANADIAN SIDE OF THE NIAGARA RIVER, A LITTLE UPSTREAM FROM THE CREST OF THE HORSESHOE FALLS, ON THE GROUNDS OF THE ONTARIO HYDROELECTRIC POWER COMPANY.  THE STATION IS ABOUT 4 FEET FROM THE EDGE OF THE RIVER BANK AT A POINT OPPOSITE THE SOUTHERNMOST END OF THE CURVE OF THE HORSESHOE FALLS.  THE BANK IS PROTECTED AT THIS POINT BY A HEAVY RIP - RAP.  THE STATION IS 5 FEET FROM A FOOTPATH AND ABOUT 70 FEET FROM THE EAST CURB OF THE BOULEVARD IN QUEEN VICTORIA PARK.  STATION MARK, AN IBC STANDARD BRONZE - DISK STATION MARK SET FLUSH WITH WITH THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND IN THE TOP OF A CYLINDER OF CONCRETE 8 INCHES IN DIAMETER AND 18 INCHES IN DEPTH.  THE SUBSURFACE MARK IS A BRASS SCREW SET 18 INCHES UNDERGROUND IN A SIMILAR CYLINDER OF CONCRETE.  STATION---LUNDY-SUB---IS 65.79 FEET FROM THE STATION, N 09 DEG 38 MIN E.                            STATION RECOVERY (1941)  RECOVERY NOTE BY INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION 1941 (JGH) STATION RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.                            STATION RECOVERY (1971)  RECOVERY NOTE BY INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION 1971 (HGD) STATION SEARCHED FOR BUT NOT RECOVERED.

IT IS SITUATED ON A CONCRETE PIER ABOUT 4 FEET FROM THE WATERS EDGE AND ABOUT 8 FEET ABOVE THE WATER LEVEL. THE STATION IS ABOUT 225 FEET NORTHEASTERLY OF A SMALL STONE OCTAGON - SHAPED GARDNERS HOUSE.  IT IS 20.48 FEET EAST OF TRIANGULATION STATION---CANAL-U.S.L.S.---WHICH IS MARKED BY A CROSS CUT IN A ONE - FOURTH INCH BOLT IN THE TOP OF A ROUGH STONE 12 BY 18 BY 18 INCHES PLACED 3 INCHES UNDERGROUND.  IT IS 21.35 FT FROM THE NORTHEAST CORNER OF THE PIER AND 5.04 FEET FROM THE SOUTHEAST CORNER OF THE PIER.  STATION MARK, A ONE - HALF INCH COPPER PLUG WITH A DRILL HOLE IN THE CENTER OF A CROSS CUT IN ONE END.  THE PLUG IS CEMENTED FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE OF THE PIER IN A DRILL HOLE IN THE CONCRETE. markers.description: DESCRIBED BY INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION 1941 (JGH) ON THE WEST BANK OF THE NIAGARA RIVER, ABOUT 1/4 MILE SOUTH OF BOYERS CREEK (SNAKE CREEK), AND ABOUT 150 FEET SOUTH OF A SIDE ROAD DEAD - ENDING INTO QUEEN VICTORIA PARKWAY.  THE STATION IS ABOUT 55 FEET EAST OF THE MACADAM ROADWAY OF THE PARKWAY AND 16 FEET EAST OF THE LINE OF WILLOW TREES ALONG THE EAST SIDE OF THE ROADWAY. MENNONITE - 1941, IS AN IBC STANDARD BRONZE - DISK STATION MARK SET IN A DRILL HOLE IN A ROCK 3 FEET BY 3 FEET BY 1 FOOT HIGH JUST OUTSIDE OF THE LINE OF WILLOW TREES AND BETWEEN THE TWO MOST NORTHERN ONES OF THE LINE. markers.description: DESCRIBED BY INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION 1941 (JGH) ON THE WEST BANK OF THE NIAGARA RIVER, ABOUT 1/4 MILE SOUTH OF BOYERS CREEK (SNAKE CREEK), AND ABOUT 150 FEET SOUTH OF A SIDE ROAD DEAD - ENDING INTO QUEEN VICTORIA PARKWAY.  THE STATION IS ABOUT 55 FEET EAST OF THE MACADAM ROADWAY OF THE PARKWAY AND 16 FEET EAST OF THE LINE OF WILLOW TREES ALONG THE EAST SIDE OF THE ROADWAY.  THE SOIL WAS SO SUBJECT TO EROSION THAT THE STATION COULD NOT BE MARKED. THERE ARE THREE WITNESSES TO THE STATION.  THE FIRST IS A 3/4 - INCH DRILL HOLE 1 INCH DEEP IN A ROCK 3 BY 2 FEET BY 1 FOOT ABOVE GROUND SOUTH OF THE STATION AND JUST OUTSIDE OF THE LINE OF WILLOW TREES. THE SECOND IS THE CENTER OF THE IRON TOP OF A DRAINAGE SUMP IN THE DITCH ON THE WEST SIDE OF THE ROADWAY AND ABOUT OPPOSITE THE FIRST WITNESS.  THE THIRD WITNESS, DESIGNATED AS MENNONITE - 1941, IS AN IBC STANDARD BRONZE - DISK STATION MARK SET IN A DRILL HOLE IN A ROCK 3 FEET BY 3 FEET BY 1 FOOT HIGH JUST OUTSIDE OF THE LINE OF WILLOW TREES AND BETWEEN THE TWO MOST NORTHERN ONES OF THE LINE.

DESCRIBED BY INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION 1941 (JGH) ON THE CANADIAN SIDE OF THE NIAGARA RIVER, ABOUT 2 MILES ABOVE NAVY ISLAND.  THE STATION IS 6 FEET FROM THE EDGE OF THE HIGH BANK OF THE RIVER, 30 FEET FROM THE RIVER, AND 12 FEET SOUTHEAST OF THE MACADAM ROAD SURFACE OF THE QUEEN VICTORIA PARKWAY.  IT IS DIRECTLY ACROSS THE ROAD FROM THE ONLY BARN ON FOX HEAD FARM WHICH FACES THE MAIN ROAD.  THE STATION IS 1 FOOT SOUTH OF THE EXTENSION ACROSS THE MAIN ROAD OF THE DITCH LINE ALONG THE SOUTH SIDE OF THE DRIVEWAY LEADING FROM THE ROAD TO THIS BARN.  IT IS ABOUT 3 FEET WEST OF A LARGE ROCK OUTCROP, 6 BY 3 FEET ON THE TOP, AT THE EDGE OF THE RIVER BANK. ACROSS THE ROAD FROM THE STATION IS A DRAIN PIPE WHICH LIES IN THE DITCH ALONG THE ROAD AND PASSES UNDER THE DRIVEWAY AT RIGHT ANGLES.  STATION MARK, AN IBC STANDARD BRONZE - DISK STATION MARK SET 2 INCHES ABOVE THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND IN THE TOP OF A CYLINDER OF CONCRETE 8 INCHES IN DIAMETER AND 14 INCHES IN DEPTH.  THE SUBSURFACE MARK IS A BRASS SCREW SET 14 INCHES UNDERGROUND IN THE TOP OF A SIMILAR CYLINDER OF CONCRETE.  THERE ARE TWO REFERENCES.  NO 1 IS A DRILL HOLE FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND IN THE TOP OF THE ROCK OUTCROP.  NO 2 IS THE CENTER OF THE TOP OF THE SOUTH END OF THE DRAIN PIPE ACROSS THE ROAD.                            STATION RECOVERY (1956)  RECOVERY NOTE BY INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION 1956 (NWS) STATION RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.  IT IS 400 FEET SOUTH OF A SIDE ROAD.                            STATION RECOVERY (1971)  RECOVERY NOTE BY INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION 1971 (HGD) THE SHANK OF THE STATION DISK AND REFERENCE NO 2 WERE RECOVERED. REFERENCE NO 1 WAS NOT RECOVERED.  THE SHANK OF THE STATION DISK IS 11 FEET WEST OF A STEEL, WITNESS POST WITH METAL SIGN ATTACHED.

markers.description: DESCRIBED BY INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION 1941 (JGH) ABOUT 3 MILES NORTH OF THE NIAGARA RIVER FALLS, ON THE HIGH CLIFF OVERLOOKING THE NIAGARA RIVER.  THE STATION IS ABOUT 84 FEET FROM NIAGARA BOULEVARD AND 30 FEET BACK FROM THE EDGE OF THE CLIFF.  IT IS ABOUT 100 FEET NORTH OF THE FIRST HIGHWAY CURVE NORTH OF THE ENTRANCE TO THE NORTH SIDE OF THE WHIRLPOOL AERIAL TRAMWAY AND 100 FEET SOUTH OF THE CURVE SOUTH OF THE CREST OF THE HILL.  IT IS ABOUT MIDWAY BETWEEN THE CLIFF AND THE ROADBED OF THE OLD NIAGARA GORGE RAILWAY.  STATION MARK, AN IBC STANDARD BRONZE - DISK STATION MARK CEMENTED IN A DRILL HOLE IN SOLID BEDROCK 8 INCHES UNDERGROUND.  THERE ARE TWO REFERENCES.  NO 1 IS AN IBC STANDARD BRONZE - DISK REFERENCE MARK CEMENTED IN AN OUTCROP OF ROCK BETWEEN THE OLD RAILWAY BED AND THE EDGE OF THE CLIFF, WITH THE ARROW POINTING TOWARD THE STATION.  NO 2 IS THE TOP OF A DRILL SET IN A CONCRETE CYLINDER ABOUT 8 INCHES IN DIAMETER.  IT IS ABOUT 15 FEET EAST OF THE EDGE OF THE HIGHWAY.                            STATION RECOVERY (1971)  RECOVERY NOTE BY INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION 1971 (HGD) THE STATION AND REFERENCE NO 1 WERE RECOVERED.  TABLET FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  REFERENCE NO 2 WAS NOT RECOVERED.  THE STATION IS 14 INCHES UNDERGROUND AND 11 FEET SOUTHEAST OF A STEEL, WITNESS POST WITH METAL SIGN ATTACHED.  IT WAS REPORTED IN 1956 THAT ONLY THE SHANK OF THE DISK REMAINED.

DESCRIBED BY INTERNATIONAL WATERWAYS COMMISSION 1909 (GCB) THE STATION WAS ORIGINALLY DESCRIBED AS BEING ON THE WEST SIDE OF THE NIAGARA RIVER ABOUT 1/3 MILE BELOW FRENCHMANS CREEK AND OPPOSITE THE MIDDLE OF STRAWBERRY ISLAND, JUST WEST OF THE MACADAM ROAD AND SOUTH OF AN OLD ORCHARD OWNED BY MR NETTLE.  STATION MARK, THE CENTER OF A 3/8-INCH BRASS PLUG, SET 1 FOOT BELOW THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND IN THE TOP OF A CONCRETE MONUMENT.  A CONCRETE MARKER 8 INCHES IN DIAMETER AND MARKED---I.W.C. 1909---WAS SET WITH ITS TOP FLUSH WITH THE GROUND 1.3 FEET SOUTH OF THE STATION. AN APPLE TREE IN THE SOUTHWEST CORNER OF THE ORCHARD IS IN AZIMUTH 79 DEGREES 06 MINUTES, 162.5 FEET DISTANT.  AN APPLE TREE IN THE SOUTHEAST CORNER OF THE ORCHARD (NEXT TO ROAD) IS IN AZIMUTH 137 DEGREES 46 MINUTES, 103.8 FEET DISTANT.                            STATION RECOVERY (1941)  RECOVERY NOTE BY INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION 1941 (JGH) THE STATION MARK WAS RECOVERED ABOUT FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND 2 FEET BELOW THE ROADBED IN THE BOTTOM OF THE DITCH ON THE WEST SIDE OF THE ROAD.  ONE SIDE OF THE CONCRETE MONUMENT WAS BROKEN AWAY ABOUT AN INCH FROM THE BRASS PLUG.  THE---MARKER---WAS NOT FOUND.  THE STATION WAS FOUND 150 FEET NORTH OF THE SOUTH END OF THE GUARD FENCE ON THE RIVER SIDE OF THE HIGHWAY AND 60 FEET SOUTH OF A TURN - OFF TO THE WEST.  ON ACCOUNT OF THE APPARENT DISTURBANCE OF THE STATION MARK AND THE OBSTRUCTION OF LINES OF SIGHT BY TREE GROWTH THE STATION WAS NOT USED.  A NEW STATION,---NETTLE-SUB---, WAS ESTABLISHED ABOUT 720 FEET TO THE SOUTHEAST.                            STATION RECOVERY (1971)  RECOVERY NOTE BY INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION 1971 (HGD) STATION RECOVERED IN POOR CONDITION.

markers.description: DESCRIBED BY INTERNATIONAL WATERWAYS COMMISSION 1909 (GCB) ON THE CANADIAN SIDE OF THE NIAGARA RIVER, ABOUT 0.6 MILE BELOW THE MOUTH OF MILLER CREEK, IN FRONT OF THE RESIDENCE OF H WORK.  THE STATION IS ON A LOW MARSHY POINT, 317 FEET FROM THE CENTER OF THE ROAD WHICH RUNS ALONG THE RIVER, AND ABOUT 50 FEET FROM THE RIVER ITSELF.  THE STATION IS 1.5 FEET NORTHEAST OF A CYLINDER OF CONCRETE MARKED---I.W.C. 1909---WHOSE TOP IS FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND.  A ROW OF 17 MAPLES BORDERS THE ROAD NEAR THE STATION.  STATION MARK, A BRASS BOLT 3/8-INCH IN DIAMETER SET 18 INCHES UNDERGROUND IN THE TOP OF A CYLINDER OF CONCRETE.  THERE IS ONE REFERENCE.  IT IS A USLS STANDARD BRONZE - DISK REFERENCE MARK SET 4 INCHES ABOVE THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND IN THE TOP OF A PIECE OF CONCRETE - FILLED STOVEPIPE.  IT IS SITUATED ON A LINE FROM THE STAION TO A LONE MAPLE AND BEARS N - 44 DEGREES - W FROM THE STATION, DISTANT 11.78 FEET.  THE MAPLE, ABOUT 2 FEET IN DIAMETER, DIVIDES ABOUT 2 FEET ABOVE THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND INTO FOUR STEMS, EACH 6 INCHES TO 1 FOOT IN DIAMETER.  A BLAZE ON THE BOTTOM OF THE TREE IS 137.8 FEET DISTANT.                            STATION RECOVERY (1956)  RECOVERY NOTE BY INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION 1956 (NWS) STATION NOT RECOVERED BUT PROBABLY RECOVERABLE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1973)  RECOVERY NOTE BY INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION 1973 (CRM) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED AND FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION.  A NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS.  THE STATION IS IN A PICNIC AREA ABOUT 4-1/2 MILES NORTHWEST OF FORT ERIE, ONTARIO.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE MILLER CREEK BRIDGE ON NIAGARA RIVER BOULEVARD, THIS IS ABOUT 5-1/2 MILES, BY ROAD, NORTHWEST OF THE INTERNATIONAL PEACE BRIDGE, GO NORTH ON THE BOULEVARD FOR 0.6 MILE TO THE SOUTH ENTRANCE TO A PICNIC AREA.  TURN RIGHT, INTO THE PICNIC AREA, AND GO EAST FOR ABOUT 200 FEET, THENCE NORTH FOR ABOUT 75 FEET TO THE STATION ON THE RIGHT.  THE STATION MARK IS A 3/8-INCH IN DIAMETER BRASS BOLT SET IN THE TOP OF A CYLINDRICAL, CONCRETE POST THAT IS 2-1/2 FEET BELOW THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND.  IT IS 8 FEET EAST OF THE EAST EDGE OF THE ROAD AND A STEEL WITNESS POST WITH METAL SIGN ATTACHED WAS SET AT THE EAST EDGE OF THE STATION MARK.  THE SITE OF THE USLS REFERENCE MARK WAS RECOVERED, BUT THE BRONZE DISK WAS GONE.  ALL THAT WAS LEFT WAS PART OF THE CONCRETE CYLINDER BROKEN OFF FLUSH WITH GROUND SURFACE.  THE 1909 IWC CONCRETE MARK, WHICH WAS REPORTED 1.5 FEET NORTHEAST OF THE STATION IN 1941 AND 1 FOOT BELOW GROUND SURFACE IN 1971, WAS NOT LOOKED FOR.

DESCRIBED BY INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION 1973 (CRM) THE STATION LOCATED ON THE INTERNATIONAL PEACE BRIDGE, CROSSING OVER THE NIAGARA RIVER, WHICH CONNECTS THE CITIES OF BUFFALO, NEW YORK AND FORT ERIE, ONTARIO. markers.description: DESCRIBED BY INTERNATIONAL WATERWAYS COMMISSION 1909 (GCB) IN THE VILLAGE OF FORT ERIE, ONTARIO, ABOUT 1/2 MILE UPSTREAM FROM THE PEACE BRIDGE, ON THE HIGHWAY NEXT TO AND PARALLELING THE RIVER FRONT, AN EXTENSION OF NIAGARA BOULEVARD.  THE STATION IS ON THE WEST SIDE OF THE HIGHWAY AND BETWEEN THE HIGHWAY AND THE SIDEWALK.  WHEN THE HIGHWAY IS REPAVED AS PLANNED IN THE NEAR FUTURE THE STATION WILL BE COVERED BY THE PAVING.  THE THREE POPLARS ORIGINALLY LISTED AS REFERENCES NOW MEASURE FROM THE STATION AS FOLLOWS--THE SOUTH POPLAR, NOW A STUMP, 31.5 FEET TO ITS FACE, THE MIDDLE POPLAR 28.7 FEET TO ITS FACE, THE NORTH POPLAR 40.9 FEET TO ITS FACE.  THE STATION MARK, A 3/8-INCH BRASS PLUG, SET IN A SMALL CONCRETE MONUMENT A FEW INCHES UNDERGROUND.  THERE ARE TWO REFERENCES. REFERENCE MARK NO 1, REFERRED TO AS---POPLARS 1941---IN THE NOTES, IS AN IBC STANDARD BRONZE - DISK STATION MARK SET FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND IN TOP OF A CYLINDER OF CONCRETE 8 INCHES IN DIAMETER AND 18 INCHES IN DEPTH.  THE SUBSURFACE MARK IS A BRASS SCREW SET IN THE TOP OF A BLOCK OF CONCRETE 18 INCHES UNDERGROUND. THE MARK IS IN A RECESS OF THE FENCE LINE ON THE SOUTH SIDE OF AN ENTRANCE DRIVEWAY, 21 FEET SOUTH OF A 2-1/2 FOOT POPLAR TREE, AND 4.25 FEET WEST OF THE CONCRETE SIDEWALK.  REFERENCE MARK NO 2 IS A DRILL HOLE IN THE TOP OF THE CONCRETE CURB ON THE WEST SIDE OF THE HIGHWAY, AT THE NORTH END OF A DRAINAGE GRILL. STATION RECOVERY (1956)  RECOVERY NOTE BY INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION 1956 (NWS) STATION LOST.

THE STATION, A .14 BY .14 FOOT WOODEN HUB NAILED TO THE EAST SIDE OF A WOODEN BLOCK AT THE BASE OF THE SOUTHERN IRON IRON ROD SUPPORT FOR THE BUILDING FLAGPOLE, IS 0.26 FOOT FROM THE NORTH END OF THE BLOCK AND 0.60 FOOT FROM THE SOUTH END OF THE BLOCK. STATION RECOVERY (1941)  RECOVERY NOTE BY INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION 1941 (JGH) FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION IN THE FRONT LAWN OF THE RESIDENCE OF DR LOWELL BUTTERS IN THE VILLAGE OF FORT ERIE, ONTARIO.  WHEN THE MONUMENT WAS SET, IT WAS IN OPEN GROUND.  SUBSEQUENTLY, THE LAND WAS DIVIDED INTO TOWN LOTS AND STREETS.  DR BUTTERS HOUSE OCCUPIES ONE OF THESE LOTS AND THE MONUMENT HAD BECOME A NUISANCE TO HIM.  IN 1940 HE MADE WRITTEN REQUEST TO HAVE THE MONUMENT REMOVED, TO WHICH THE COMMISSIONERS AGREED.  ACCORDINGLY, THE MONUMENT WAS REMOVED FROM ITS ORIGINAL POSITION AND RESET ON THE HIGH BANK BETWEEN THE RIVER AND THE PAVED STREET THAT PARALLELS THE RIVER BANK.  THE NEW POSITION IS ABOUT 67 FEET NORTHEAST OF THE ORIGINAL POSITION.  THE GEOGRAPHIC POSITION OF THE MONUMENT IN ITS NEW POSITION WAS DETERMINED BY TRIANGULATION FROM REFERENCE MONUMENTS 32 AND 34, AND THE AZIMUTHS AND DISTANCES TO BOUNDARY TURNING POINTS 150 AND 151 WERE COMPUTED. THE DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC WORKS, CANADA, BENCH MARK MMDXCIII, A COPPER BOLT IN THE SIDE OF THE MONUMENT, WAS LOWERED 2.018 FEET BY THE MOVING OF THE MONUMENT.  THE MONUMENT WAS MOVED ON SEPTEMBER 29, 1941.

NO 1 IS A PUNCH HOLE IN THE COPING OF THE WALL AT A POINT DIRECTLY ABOVE A 1 - INCH DRILL HOLE WHICH IS 2.1 FEET ABOVE THE SURFACE OF THE SIDEWALK.  THE LINE FROM THE REFERENCE TO THE STATION MAKES A RIGHT ANGLE WITH THE RIVER.  NO 2 IS A SIMILAR MARK DIRECTLY ABOVE ANOTHER 1 - INCH DRILL HOLE SITUATED 2.1 FEET ABOVE THE SURFACE OF THE SIDEWALK.  THIS REFERENCE IS ON THE OPPOSITE SIDE OF THE STATION FROM THE UNITED OFFICE BUILDING IN NIAGARA FALLS, NEW YORK, AND ON LINE WITH THE TWO. markers.description: DESCRIBED BY INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION 1941 (JGH) ON THE CANADIAN SIDE OF THE NIAGARA RIVER ABOUT 1-1/4 MILES SOUTH OF POINT ELINOR. IT IS ABOUT 75 FEET EAST OF A ROADWAY LEADING NORTH FROM THE HIGHWAY TO THE RIVER.  THE STATION IS ON THE SLOPE WHICH RUNS FROM THE HIGHWAY TO A MARSH AT THE WATERS EDGE.  IT IS ABOUT 300 FEET FROM THE SOUTHERN END OF A ROW OF 10 - INCH SPRUCE TREES EXTENDING FOR A DISTANCE OF ABOUT 800 FEET ALONG THE WEST SIDE OF THE HIGHWAY.  STATION MARK, AN IBC STANDARD BRONZE - DISK STATION MARK SET FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND IN THE TOP OF A CYLINDER OF CONCRETE 6 INCHES IN DIAMETER AND 2 FEET IN DEPTH. NO 2, 28 FEET NORTH EAST OF THE HIGHWAY, IS AN IBC STANDARD BRONZE - DISK STATION MARK CEMENTED IN A 6 BY 6 INCH GRANITE ROCK WHICH PROJECTS 1 INCH ABOVE THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND.  BOTH REFERENCES HAVE ARROWS POINTING TOWARD THE STATION. markers.description: DESCRIBED BY INTERNATIONAL WATERWAYS COMMISSION 1909 (GCB) ON THE CANADIAN SIDE OF THE NIAGARA RIVER, ABOUT 4 MILES BELOW THE INTERNATIONAL BRIDGE.  THE STATION IS 400 FEET ABOVE THE MOUTH OF MILLER CREEK, 45 FEET NORTHEAST OF THE CENTER OF QUEEN VICTORIA PARKWAY, AND 25 FEET FROM THE RIVER BANK.  IT IS ONE FOOT NORTH OF A CYLINDER OF CONCRETE WHOSE TOP IS FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND.  STATION MARK, A BRASS BOLT 3/8-INCH IN DIAMETER SET 1 FOOT UNDERGROUND IN THE TOP OF A CYLINDER OF CONCRETE.  THERE ARE TWO REFERENCES.  NO 1 IS A USLS STANDARD BRONZE - DISK REFERENCE MARK SET 2 INCHES ABOVE THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND IN THE TOP OF A CYLINDER OF CONCRETE.  THE REFERENCE IS SITUATED IN A ROW OF SMALL MAPLES 20 FEET NORTHEAST OF THE CENTER OF QUEEN VICTORIA PARKWAY AND BEARS S - 63 DEGREES - W FROM THE STATION, DISTANT 26.79 FEET.  NO 2 IS AN ARROW CUT ON THE STONE COPING OF THE SOUTHEAST WING WALL OF THE BRIDGE OVER MILLER CREEK.  IT BEARS N - 32 DEGREES - W FROM THE STATION, DISTANT 369.53 FEET.  THE ARROW IN BRIDGE IS OK, THE REFERENCE CYLINDER OF CONCRETE IS BROKEN OFF 6 INCHES UNDERGROUND. IT IS IN A HOLE 21 FEET UPSTREAM FROM THE 6TH TREE SOUTH OF THE BRIDGE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1956)  RECOVERY NOTE BY INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION 1956 (NWS) STATION NOT RECOVERED BUT PROBABLY RECOVERABLE.                            STATION RECOVERY (1973)  RECOVERY NOTE BY INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION 1973 (CRM) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED AND FOUND IN GOOD CONDTION.  A NEW DESCRIPTION FOLLOWS.  THE STATION IS LOCATED ABOUT 4 MILES NORTHWEST OF FORT ERIE, ONTARIO AND ON NIAGARA PARKS COMMISSION PROPERTY.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE BRIDGE OVER MILLER CREEK ON NIAGARA RIVER BOULEVARD, THIS IS ABOUT 5-1/2 MILES, BY ROAD, NORTHWEST OF THE INTERNATIONAL PEACE BRIDGE, GO SOUTH ON THE BOULEVARD FOR 0.05 MILE TO THE STATION ON THE LEFT, IN A GROVE OF MAPLE TREES.  THE STATION MARK IS A 3/8-INCH IN DIAMETER BRASS BOLT SET IN THE TOP OF A CYLINDRICAL, CONCRETE POST THAT IS 1 FOOT BELOW THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND.  IT IS 49 FEET NORTHEAST OF THE CENTER OF THE BOULEVARD, 32 FEET SOUTHWEST OF THE RIVER BANK, AND 6.2 FEET EAST OF A STEEL, WITNESS POST WITH METAL SIGN ATTACHED.

markers.description: DESCRIBED BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1972 (HLM) STATION IS LOCATED ATOP THE SKYLON OBSERVATION TOWER (TALLEST 1 OF 3) IN DOWNTOWN NIAGARA FALLS CANADA.  THE STATION IS MARKED BY AN UNSTAMPED 1/2 INCH BRONZE PLUG EMBEDDED IN THE NYLON SURFACE OF THE ROOF.  IT IS 4 FEET NORTH OF THE NORTH EDGE OF THE TAPERED METAL POLE IN THE CENTER OF THE ROOF AND 3 FEET EAST OF THE DOOR LEADING TO THE ROOF.  SKYLON SPIRE IS A TAPERED METAL POLE APPROXIMATELY 50 FEET IN HEIGHT LOCATED IN THE APPROXIMATE CENTER OF THE ROOF.  NOTE--NO REFERENCE MARKS WERE SET AT THE REQUEST OF THE PROPERTY OWNER.  NEAREST TOWN--NIAGARA FALLS.  HEIGHT OF LIGHT ABOVE STATION MARK 1.5 METERS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1973)  RECOVERY NOTE BY NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY 1973 (CRM) THE STATION WAS RECOVERED AS DESCRIBED AND FOUND IN GOOD CONDITION. THE DESCRIPTION BY THE NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY IS ADEQUATE.  THERE IS SOME CONFUSION ABOUT THE CORRECT DESIGNATION FOR THIS STATION.  THE NATIONAL GEODETIC SURVEY REFERS TO THIS POINT AS SKYLON, BUT THE GEODETIC SURVEY OF CANADA DESIGNATES THE FLASHING RED LIGHT ON THE TOP OF THE SKYLON AS SKYLON.  OUR (INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION) OBSERVATIONS WERE MADE FROM THE 1/2 - INCH BRONZE PLUG DESCRIBED IN THE 1972 NGS DESCRIPTION BY GMB.                            STATION RECOVERY (1991)  RECOVERY NOTE BY US POWER SQUADRON 1991 (HEE) RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.

markers.description: DESCRIBED BY GEODETIC SURVEY OF CANADA 1910 IN ST ARMAND SEIGNEURY, ON THE TOP OF A MOUNTAIN CALLED THE PINNACLE.  THE STATION IS MOST EASILY REACHED FROM THE TOWN OF RICHFORD, VT, ON THE NEWPORT AND BOSTON BRANCH OF THE CANADIAN PACIFIC RAILWAY, BY A DRIVE OF 4 MILES TO THE FARM OF FS CLARK, AND THENCE BY WAY OF A PATH LEADING FROM THE BACK OF HIS FARM TO THE TOP OF THE MOUNTAIN.  THE TOP OF THE MOUNTAIN IS ALMOST BARE ROCK, WITH SCATTERED SMALL SCRUB.  AN UBOBSTRUCTED VIEW CAN BE HAD IN ALL DIRECTIONS.  TO THE NORTH OF THE SUMMIT IS A TRIANGULATION STATION USED BY THE MILITIA DEPARTMENT, MARKED BY A COPPER BOLT WITH A CROSS ON IT.  THE SUMMIT OF THE HILL IS A FLAT ROCK, WHICH WAS SELECTED AS THE BEST LOCATION FOR THE STATION.  STATION MARK--COPPER BOLT LEADED IN THE ROCK.  AN EQUILATERAL TRIANGLE IS CUT AROUND IT, THE BOLT IS STAMPED WITH THE CANADIAN GEODETJIC SURVEY DIE, IT IS REFERENCED BY THE TRIANGULATION MARK OF THE CANADIAN MILITIA DEPARTMENT AND BY THREE ARROWS CUT IN THE ROCK, WITH COPPER BOLTS AT THEIR POINTS.                            STATION RECOVERY (1975)  RECOVERY NOTE BY INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION 1975 (NP) STATION WAS RECOVERED IN GOOD CONDITION.

markers.description: DESCRIBED BY INTERNATIONAL BOUNDARY COMMISSION 1973 (CRM) THE STATION IS LOCATED BETWEEN QUEENSTON, ONTARIO AND NIAGARA FALLS, ONTARIO, ATOP THE RESERVOIR FOR THE SIR ADAM BECK GENERATING PLANT.  TO REACH THE STATION FROM THE NORTH END OF THE SIR ADAM BECK GENERATING PLANT, GO NORTHERLY ON THE PARKWAY FOR 0.15 MILE TO A REVERSE Y - FORK TO THE LEFT.  TURN SHARP LEFT AND GO SOUTHWEST FOR 0.05 MILE TO A Y - FORK.  TAKE THE RIGHT FORK AND GO WESTERLY FOR 0.4 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT.  CONTINUE AHEAD, SOUTHWEST, FOR 0.2 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND GO NORTHERLY FOR 0.1 MILE TO A SIDE ROAD RIGHT.  TURN RIGHT AND GO EAST FOR 0.1 MILE TO A Y - FORK. TAKE THE LEFT FORK AND GO NORTH FOR 0.1 MILE TO THE TOP OF THE RESERVOIR.  TURN SHARP RIGHT AND GO EASTERLY, ALONG THE TOP OF THE RESERVOIR, FOR 0.55 MILE TO THE STATION ON THE RIGHT.  THIS IS AT A POINT WHERE THE ROAD STARTS TURNING TO THE LEFT, NORTH.  THE STATION MARK, STAMPED WATER IBC 1973, IS A BRONZE DISK CRIMPED TO THE TOP OF A 9/16 - INCH IN DIAMETER, COPPER - COATED, STEEL ROD THAT IS DRIVEN INTO THE GROUND AND PROJECTS 4 INCHES.  IT IS 9 FEET SOUTHEAST OF THE CENTER OF THE ROAD.
markers.setting: undefinedMETAL ROD DRIVEN INTO GROUND. SEE TEXT FOR ADDITIONAL

THE STATION IS ABOUT 10 FEET SOUTH OF THE CLIFFS EDGE.  STATION MARK, AN IBC STANDARD BRONZE - DISK STATION MARK SET FLUSH WITH THE SURFACE OF THE GROUND IN THE TOP OF A CYLINDER OF CONCRETE 8 INCHES IN DIAMETER AND 15 INCHES IN DEPTH.  THE SUBSURFACE MARK IS A BRONZE PLUG SET 15 INCHES UNDERGROUND IN THE TOP OF A CYLINDER OF CONCRETE 10 INCHES IN DIAMETER AND 18 INCHES IN DEPTH.  THERE ARE TWO REFERENCES.  NO 1, 35.6 FEET WEST OF THE STATION, IS THE CONCRETE PIER UNDER THE EAST CORNER OF THE SMALL BUILDING AT THE LANDING. NO 2 IS A DRILL HOLE, 1 INCH IN DIAMETER AND 1 INCH IN DEPTH IN THE TOP OF A GRANITE - TOPPED STONE WALL ALONG THE SIDEWALK LEADING TO THE LANDING, 55.6 FEET SOUTH OF THE STATION.
